instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.820-3435: What is 820-3435? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> Power Cycling  <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>
threads.message: Hey guys working on on this <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> air no water damage, customer used the mac one morning and shut it down came back to use it and it would not turn on. iItried smc reset at first but noting happened, green light did not cycle from green to orange. Tried this twice with no luck that's when i started to check the rails. Is the smc at fault, or is it something else telling the smc to power cycle <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> Power Cycling  <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>
threads.message: Did you try a new battery? I'd try that and if not plug in charger with battery unplugged just to rule it out

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> Power Cycling  <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>
threads.message:
Why would a battery fix this? It power on fine without battery.

Is the green/orange light present? PPBUS voltage? <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> pulsing high?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> Power Cycling  <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>
threads.message: I've had boards that don't turn on in with a bad battery plugged in that's the only reason I thought it could cause issues.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> Power Cycling  <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 27427"]Why would a battery fix this? It power on fine without battery.

Is the green/orange light present? PPBUS voltage? <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> pulsing high?[/QUOTE]

Charger light is present and solid Pbus Voltage steady 8.59 <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is pulsing hi 3.3v

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> Power Cycling  <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>
threads.message: All boards will turn on if the correct charger is used. So always use 85W REAL ORIGINAL chargers for testing.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> Power Cycling  <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>
threads.message: This is usually the SMC or <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> Power Cycling  <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 27444"]This is usually the SMC or <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>.[/QUOTE]

Once again Duke right on the money replaced <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> back to life mark as solved !
